work.p: The notebook contains draft lines of a poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures." The first several lines of the notebook draft were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

Grier notes the similarities between this line and the following, in "Salut au Monde!": "I see a great round wonder rolling through the air" (1860, p. 246). There is also some similarity in subject, if not wording, in discussions of Greek, Hebrew, Christ, and Hindu in "Salut au Monde!" See what would become section 6: "I see where druids walked the groves of Mona—I see the mistletoe and vervain" (1860, p. 249).

A line in this manuscript was used in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "The pride of the United States leaves the wealth and finesse of the cities and all returns of commerce and agriculture and all the magnitude of geography or shows of exterior victory to enjoy the breed of fullsized men or one fullsized man unconquerable and simple" (1855, pp. iii–iv). The line about "a merry recruiter" may also relate distantly to the following line in the 1855 preface to Leaves of Grass: "Who recruits him recruits horse and foot . . . he fetches parks of artillery the best that engineer ever knew."

Both Emory Holloway and Grier point to similarities between wording in passages from this notebook and "Song of Myself." The "old European martyrdom" may relate to the following lines, from the poem that would become "Song of Myself": "The disdain and calmness of martyrs, / The mother condemned for a witch and burnt with dry wood, and her children gazing on" (1855, p. 39). In the early notebook "Poem incarnating the mind," versions of these lines are followed by the line: "The great queens that walked serenely to the block." This line was dropped in published versions of the poem.

The "Lucifer" portrait may relate to a "Lucifer" segment included in early editions of Leaves of Grass but ultimately cut from the final version of "The Sleepers": "Now Lucifer was not dead . . . . or if he was I am his sorrowful terrible heir; / I have been wronged . . . . I am oppressed . . . . I hate him that oppresses me, / I will either destroy him, or he shall release me" (1855, p. 74). For a discussion of the revision history of that poem, see Brett Barney, Ed Folsom, and Kenneth M. Price, "The Changing Shape of 'The Sleepers,' with special attention to the 'Lucifer' passage." See also Ed Folsom, "Walt Whitman's 'The Sleepers,'" in The Classroom Electric.

Two lines in this manuscript may relate to what would become section 1 of "Starting from Paumanok": "Or a solider camp'd or carrying my knapsack and gun, or a miner in California, / Or rude in my home in Dakota's woods, my diet meat, my drink from the spring" (1891, p. 18), as well as section 14: "Yet Kanadian cheerily braving the winter, the snow and ice welcome to me" (1891, p. 27).
The ideas expressed in this manuscript bear some resemblance to lines in the poem that would be titled "To Think of Time," beginning with "The law of the past cannot be eluded" (1855, p. 68).

The last two lines in this manuscript bear some resemblance to language in the poem eventually titled "A Song for Occupations": "The wonder every one sees in every one else he sees . . . . and the wonders that fill each minute of time forever and each acre of surface and space forever" (1855, p. 59).

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Emory Holloway first dated this holograph notebook, which has been bound with a blue ribbon, around 1850, but Edward Grier argues that it must have been from 1855 at the earliest, based on relations to other manuscripts and the Owen and Hurlburt paper that makes up the notebook. Whitman used this paper for other manuscripts in 1859 and 1860. Page numbering and edits in blue pencil were probably made later. Lines from this notebook are similar to a series of notes written by Whitman in the 1850s, and some of the segments that were clipped out of the notebook are held at the Library of Congress (see loc.00216). See also tex.00042 and uva.00061. The first several lines of the notebook draft were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. Sections of the notebook are similar in both subject matter and wording to segments of Leaves of Grass, including most prominently the poem eventually titled "Salut au Monde!" Imagery and language included in this notebook also appear in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass and the poems eventually titled "Song of Myself," "Starting from Paumanok," and "The Sleepers." For a more extensive list of relationships to published poems and other notebooks, see Notebooks and Unpublished Prose (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 4:1295.

body.head: Pictures.
body.note:
Break all this into several "pictures"
Walt Whitman

lg.l:
In a little house pictures I keep, ¶ many
pictures hanging suspended—
It is not a fixed house,

It is round—it is but a few
inches from one side of it
to the other side,

—Here! do you know this? This
is cicerone himself;

And here, one after another, see
you, my own States—and
there here the world itself, rolling bowling
through the air;

And there, on the walls hanging, portraits
of women and men, carefully kept,

This is the portrait of my dear
mother—and this of my father—
and these of my brothers and
sisters;

This, (I name every thing as it
comes,) This is a beautiful statue,
long lost, dark buried, but never
destroyed—and now found by me,
and again restored to the light;

There five stalwart men, a group
of sworn friends, stalwart bearded, deter‑
mined, work their way together
through all the troubles and impediments of the world;

And that is a magical wondrous
mirror—long it lay clouded, but
the cloud has pass'd away,

It is now a clean and bright
mirror—it will show you all
things you can conceive of, or all
you wish to behold;

And that is a picture of intended for Death—
it is very beautiful—(what else
is so beautiful as Death?)

There is represented the Day, full of
effulgence—full of seminal lust and love—
full of action, life, strength, aspi-
ration,

And there the Night, with mystic
beauty, full of love also, and
full of greater life—the Night,
showing where the stars are;

There is a picture of Adam
in Paradise—side by side
with him Eve, (the Earth's bride
and the Earth's bridegroom;)

There are Hebrew prophets, chanting,
rapt, extaticecstatic—and here is Homer;

Here is one singing canticles in
an unknown tongue, before
the Sansckrit was,

And here a Hindu sage, with his
recitative in Sansckrit;

And here the divine Christ ex-
pounds the eternal truths—ex-
pounds the Soul,

And here he again appears en-route
to Calvary, bearing the cross—
See you, the blood and sweat
streaming down his face, his neck;

And here, behold, a picture of
once imperial Rome, full
of palaces—full of masterful
warriors;

And here, arguing, the questioner, the Athenian of
the classical time—Socrates, this,
in the market-place,

del.l:
(O divine tongue! I too grow silent
under your elenchus,

lg.l:
O you with bare feet, and bulging belly! I
saunter along, following you,
and obediently listen;)

And here Athens itself, of —it is a clear
forenoon, two thousand years
before These States,

Young men, pupils, collect in
the gardens of their a some favorite master,
waiting for him,

Some, crowded in groups, listen
to the harangues or arguments of the elder
ones,

Elsewhere, single figures, undisturbed
by the buzz around them, lean
against pillars, or within re-
cesses, meditating, or studying
from manuscripts,

Here and there, couples or trios, of
men, young and old, clear-faced, and of perfect
physique, walk with twined arms,
in divine friendship, happy,

Till, beyond, the master appears, advancing
—his form shows above the
crowd, a head taller than they,

His gait is erect, calm and dignified
—his features are grand, colossal
and regular—he is old, yet
his forehead has no wrinkles,

Wait till he speaks—what God's
voice is it then, that, sounding from
his mouth?

He places virtue and self-denial
above all the rest,

He shows to what a glorious height
the young men man may ascend,

—And here again, and again, that this picture
tells a story of the Olympic
games,

See you, the chariot races? See
you, the boxers boxing, and the
runners running?

See you, the poets off there reciting
their poems and tragedies, to crowds of listeners?

This again is a series after the
great French revolution,

This is the taking of the BastileBastille,
the prison—this is the ex-
ecution of the king,

—But this opposite, (abruptly changing,)
is a picture from the prison-
ships of my own old city—Brooklyn city, my own
old city;

And there is an old European
martyrdom—See you, the crackling
fire—See the agonized contortions
of the limbs, and the writhing
of the lips! See the head thrown back;

And here is a picture of triumph—
a General has returned, after
a victory—the city turns out
to meet him,

And here is a portrait of the English
king, Charles the First, (are you
a judge of physiognomy?)
And—But there is a curious group on

And here is a funeral procession
in the country,

A beloved daughter is carried in her coffin—
there follow the parents and neighbors;

And here, see you—here walks the
Boston truckman, by the side
of his string-team—see you,
the three horses, pacing so
stately, so sagacious, one ahead
of another;
—And this—whose picture is this?

Who is this, with rapid feet,
curious, gay—going up and
down Mannahatta, through the
streets, along the shores, working
his way through the crowds,
observant and singing?

But this other ¶ And this head of Dante Italian, melancholy Dante, poet of penalties—poet of hell is a portrait of
ShakespearShakespeare, limner of feudal
European lords—and this of Italian,
melancholy Dante, poet of penalties—poet of hell— (here are my
hands, my brothers—one for each
of you;)

And that is a picture of a
fish-market—see there the
shad, flat-fish, the large halibut,
—there a pile of lobsters, and
there another of oysters;

Opposite, a drudge is in the
kitchen, working, tired—and
there again the laborer, in
stained clothes, sour-smelling,
sweaty—and again black persons
and criminals,

And there the frivolous person—
and there a crazy enthusiast—
and there a young man lying lies
sick of a fever, and is soon to
die;

And here, see you, a picture of a
dream of despair, (—from is it unsatisfied love?)

Phantoms,—countless, men and women,
after death, wandering;

But see this!—see where, graceful and stately, the young
queen-cow walks graceful and
X stately at the head of a the large
drove, leading the rest;

And there are building materials—
brick, lime, timber, paint, glass,
and iron, (so now you can build
what you like;

And this black portrait—this head,
huge, frowning, sorrowful,—I
think it is Lucifer's portrait—
the denied God's portrait,

(But I do not deny him—though
cast out and rebellious, he is
my God as much as any;)

And again the heads of three other
Gods—the gGod Beauty, the God
Beneficence, and the God Univer-
sality, (they also are mine, also;)

And there are my woods of KanadaCanada,
in winter, with ice and snow,

And there, rude grave‑mounds in
California—and there a path
worn in the grass,

And here are mechanics working in
their shops, in towns—There is
the carpenter, shoving shoves his jack‑plane—
—there the blacksmith stands
by his anvil, leaning on an a great an his
upright hammer;

This is Chicago, my great city,
with railroad depots, with trains
arriving and departing—and, in their
places, immense stores of grain,
meat, and lumber;

And here are my slave‑gangs, South,
at work upon the roads, the women
indifferently with the men—see, you,
how clumsy, hideous, black, pouting,
grinning, sly, besotted, sensual,
shameless;

And this of a scene afar in the
North, the arctic—those are the corpses
of lost explorers, (no chaplets
of roses will ever cap those their icy
graves—but I give put you a
chaplet here, in this poem, for you, you sturdy English herosheroes;)

But here, now, copious—see, you, here,
the Wonders of eld, the famed Seven,

The Olympian statue this, and this
the Artemesian tomb,

Pyramid this, Pharos this, and this
the shrine of Diana,

These Babylon's gardens, and this Rhodes'
high‑lifted marvel,
because all the world, and all the
inventions of the world, are but
food for the body and sSoul of one

(But for all of them, that, nigh, at hand, see, you, a wonder
beyond any of them,

Namely, yourself—the form and thoughts
of a man,

A man! what is because all the world, —what and all
are all the works of the world the inventions of the world are but the
in comparison with one man— food of the body and the soul of
namely, with you?) one man;)

—And here, while ages have grown
upon ages,

Pictures of youths and greybeards,
Pagan, and Jew, and Christian,

Some retiring to caves—some to in
schools inand piled libraries,

To pore with ceaseless fervor over
the myth of the Infinite,

But ever recoiling, Pagan and Jew
and Christian,

—And here now, (for all varieties, I say,
hang in this little house,)

A cautious string of the my Iroquois,
the aborigines—see you, where
they march in single file, without
noise, very cautious, through passages in the
old woods;

And here Of a husking‑frolic in the
West—see you, the large rude
room barn—see you, young
and old, laughing and joking,
husking as they husk the ears of corn;

And there in a city, a stormy
political meeting—a torch‑light
procession—candidates avowing
themselves to the people;

And here is the Lascar I noticed
once in Asia—here he remains
still, pouring money into the sea,
as an offering to demons, for
favor;

And there, in the midst of a group,
a quelledquell'd revolted slave, cowering,

See you, the hand‑cuffs, the hopple,
and the blood‑stained cowhide;

And there handg, side by side, certain
close comrades of mine—the a Broadway
stage‑driver, the a lumberman
of Maine, and the a deck‑hand of
the a Mississippi steamboat;

transpose.l:
And there, tall and slender, stands is Ralph Waldo Emerson, of
New England, standing up, tall and slender at the
lecturer's desk lecturing,

lg.l: And again a the young man of Mannahatta, the celebrated rough,

(Here He Him tThe one I love well—let others sing whom they may— here him I sing,
for a thousand years!;)

—And there a historic piece—see you,
where Thomas Jefferson of of Virginia sits reading
Rousseau, the Swiss, and then com‑
piling the Declaration of Inde‑
pendence, the American compact;

And here, behold these two war‑ships saluting
each other—behold the smoke, bulging, rising spreading
in round clouds from the guns and
sometimes hiding the ships;

And there, on the level banks of the
James river, in Virginia, stand the mansions
of the Virginia planters:

And here an old black man, stone‑
blind, with a placard on his hat, sits is sitting low at the corner, of a street,
begging, humming hymn‑tunes nasally all day
to himself and receiving the small gifts;

And this, out at sea, is a signal‑
bell—see you, how where it is built
on a reef, and ever dolefully keeps
tolling, to warn mariners;

And this picture tells shows what once
happened in one of Napoleon's greatest battles,

(The tale was conveyed to me by an
old French soldier,)

In the height of the roar and carnage
of the battle, all of a sudden,
from some unaccountable cause,
the whole fury of the opposing armies
subsided—there was a perfect calm,

It lasted almost a minute—not a gun
was fired—all was petrified,

It was more solemn and awful than
all the following roar and slaughter;

—And here, (for still I name them as
they come,) here are my timber‑
towers, guiding logs down a stream
in the North;

And here a glimpse of my treeless
llanos, where they skirt the Colo‑
rado, and sweep for a thousand
miles on either side of the
Rocky Mountains;

And there, on the whaling ground, in
X the Pacific, is a sailor, perched
at the top‑mast head, on the
look out,
lg.metamark: ☞ take this out a ¶ by itself
lg.l:
(But here, (look you well,) see here the phallic
choice of America, a full‑sized
man or woman—a natural,
well‑trained man or woman

(The phallic choice of America leaves
the finesse of cities, and all the
returns of commerce or agriculture,
or and the magnitude of geography,
and achievements of literature and
art, and all the shows of exterior
victory, to enjoy the breeding
of full‑sized men, or one full‑
sized man or woman, unconquer‑
able and simple;)

—For all such those have I in the a
round house hanging—such
pictures have I—and they are
but little,

For wherever I have been, has
afforded me such superb pictures,

And whatever I have heard has
given me its perfect pictures,

And every hour of the day and
night has given deposited with me its copious
pictures,

And every rod of land or sea
yet still affords me, as long as I live, inimitable
pictures.
